::: {#a.-split-the-book-text-into-chapters-including-etymology-and-epilogue .section .level5}
### 2. Spliting the text book 

``` r
mobey_substr = substr(mobey_dick, 9750, 1385371) # generate sub string from the index of etymology (9750), to the index of the epilogue ending (1385371)

all_chapters = unlist(strsplit(mobey_substr, split = "\r\n    \r\n      \r\n       \r\n    \r\n    \r\n      \r\n    \r\n"))

divided_book = list()
chpaters_lengths = c()
for (i in 1:length(all_chapters)){
  divided_book[[i]] = unlist(strsplit(all_chapters[i], "\\W+"))
  chpaters_lengths[i] = length(divided_book[[i]])
}

divided_book_array = array(divided_book)


df_for_plot = cbind.data.frame(c(1:137), chpaters_lengths)
colnames(df_for_plot) = c('chapter', 'length')
ggplot(data = df_for_plot) + aes_string(x='chapter', y='length') + 
      geom_line(col="skyblue3") +
      theme_bw() +
      labs(x="Chapter", y = 'Chapter length', title=("Chapters lengths from Etymology (1) to Epilogue (137)")) +  scale_x_discrete(limits = c("Etm", seq(1,135), "Epy"), breaks = c("Etm", seq(10,135,10), "Epy"))
```

::: {#b.-function-for-relative-frequencies-of-words-by-chapter. .section .level5}
##### b. function for relative frequencies of words by chapter.

``` r
genereate_word_freq = function(word, chapters){
  ctr = 0
  prob_vec = c()
  for (i in 1:137){
    for (x in chapters[[i]]){
      if (x == word){
        ctr = ctr +1
      }
    }
    prob_vec[i] = ctr / length(chapters[[i]])
    ctr = 0
  }
  prob_vec
}

Ahab_probs = genereate_word_freq('Ahab', divided_book_array)
Moby_probs = genereate_word_freq('Moby', divided_book_array)
sea_probs =  genereate_word_freq('sea',  divided_book_array)
chapter = c(1:137)
probs_df_words = cbind.data.frame(chapter, Ahab_probs, Moby_probs, sea_probs)

pl1 = ggplot(probs_df_words) + aes_string(x='chapter', y= 'Ahab_probs') + 
  geom_point(col="skyblue3") + theme_bw() +
  labs(x="Chapter", y ="'Ahab' Probabillity",title=("'Ahab' P by chapters")) + scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(seq(1, 137, 20)))

pl2 = ggplot(probs_df_words) + aes_string(x='chapter', y= 'Moby_probs') + 
  geom_point(col="firebrick") + theme_bw() +
  labs(x="Chapter", y ="'Moby' Probabillity",title=("'Moby' P by chapters")) + scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(seq(1, 137, 20)))


pl3 = ggplot(probs_df_words) + aes_string(x='chapter', y= 'sea_probs') + 
  geom_point(col="darksalmon") + theme_bw() +
  labs(x="Chapter", y = "'sea' Probabillity", title=("'sea' P by chapters")) + scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(seq(1, 137, 20)))

ggarrange(pl1, pl2, pl3, ncol=3)
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

By looking at the 3 graphs we can see that `sea` is more common among
the chapters, `Ahab` has the largest frequency in chapter 109, `Moby`
has the largest frequency in chapter 36, `sea` has the largest frequency
in chapter 56. `Moby` frequency has the largest variation, `sea` has the
smallest variattion.
:::
:::

::: {#q3 .section .level3}

::: {#a.-probability-of-picking-the-same-word-caclulate-then-simulate .section .level5}
### 3. Probability,Caclulate&Simulate

``` r
# (i)

words_prop = words_freq %>% group_by(Word) %>% summarise(same_word_freq = (Freq/word_num)^2)

sum(words_prop$same_word_freq)
```

    ## [1] 0.008497684

``` r
# (ii)

set.seed(2)

same_word_prop_func = function(n){
  vec = mobey_words_in_line[[1]]
  ctr = 0
    for (i in 1:n){
      samp = sample(vec, 2, replace = TRUE)
      num_words = length(unique(samp))
      if (num_words == 1){
        ctr = ctr + 1
    }
    }
  return(ctr/n)
}

same_word_prop_func(100000)
```

    ## [1] 0.00908

i.  As the pick is independent: [\\\[Pr(same\_{word}) = \\sum\_{i =
    1}\^{num\_{words}}p({word\^2_i}) = \\cup\_{i =
    1}\^{num\_{words}}p({word\^2_i}) \\\]]{.math .display} We created a
    data frame that contains all the squared probabilities and than used
    `sum` on all the probabilities to get the union of all the
    probabilities (since they are independent).

ii. We sampled 100000 times 2 words from the book it self and returned
    the number of times the same word was sampled independently.
:::

::: {#b.-unique-words-same-word-probabillity .section .level5}
##### b. unique words, same word probabillity

``` r
unique_words = subset(words_freq, Freq == 1, select = Word) %>% filter(Word != '')

word_p  = 1/lengths(unique_words) # True for any unique word
same_unique_word_p = as.numeric(word_p)^2 # independently picking the same word 
  
print(same_unique_word_p*length(unique_words$Word)) # sum of all options (Union)
```

    ## [1] 0.000117096

[\\\[Pr(same\_{word}) = \\sum\_{i = 1}\^{num\_{words}}p({word\^2_i}) =
\\cup\_{i = 1}\^{num\_{words}}p({word\^2_i}) =\^{iid} num\_{words} \*
p({word\^2_i})\\\]]{.math .display} There are around 8.5K of unique
words compare to around 222K of total words. while checking the
probability for any unique word we get (1/8.5K) its approximately
(26/222K). but, since we have some very high frequent words the Union of
probabilities is higher in the non-unique and we get lower probability
in the unique words for same_word_p.Â 
:::
:::

::: {#b.-compute-letter-frequencies-statistics-of-the-five-letter-words-show-on-heatmap .section .level5}
##### b. Compute letter frequencies statistics of the five-letter words, show on heatmap

``` r
connected_letters_vec = function(data, var){
  ind = rep("", 5)
  for(i in data[var]){ # ind[i] = all letters of index i in the words
    for (j in 1:5){ 
      ind[j] = paste(ind[j], strrep(substr(i, j, j),five_letters$Freq[five_letters$Word==i]),
                     sep = "", collapse = '')
    }
  }
return(ind)
}

five_let_ind = connected_letters_vec(five_letters, 'Word')

freq_by_ind = cbind.data.frame( # data frame of all letter freq by index 
  as.data.frame(table(c(letters, strsplit(five_let_ind[1],   "")[[1]]))-1),
  as.data.frame(table(c(letters, strsplit(five_let_ind[2],   "")[[1]]))-1)[-2,]$Freq,
  as.data.frame(table(c(letters, strsplit(five_let_ind[3],   "")[[1]]))-1)$Freq,
  as.data.frame(table(c(letters, strsplit(five_let_ind[4],   "")[[1]]))-1)$Freq,
  as.data.frame(table(c(letters, strsplit(five_let_ind[5],   "")[[1]]))-1)[-2,]$Freq)


colnames(freq_by_ind) = c("Letter", "ind_1","ind_2","ind_3","ind_4","ind_5")

gen_heatmap = function(data){
  heatmap(data.matrix(data[-1]),Rowv = NA,Colv = NA, col =  colorRampPalette(brewer.pal(8, "Greens"))(5))
legend(x="bottomright", legend=c("Min", "Avg", "Max"),
       fill=colorRampPalette(brewer.pal(8, "Greens"))(3))
}

gen_heatmap(freq_by_ind)
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}
As we can see most words start with (b, f, j, m, p, q, t, v) and end
with the letters (d, e, k, y). We can also say that words almost doesn't
start with (e, i, r) and end with (c, i, o, u, v)
:::

::: {#c.-function-calculating-likehood-of-five-letter-words-showing-top-10-table .section .level5}
##### c.Â function calculating likehood of five letter words, showing top 10 table

``` r
generate_est = function(word, probs){ # MLE estimator by multiplying all letters prob
  splitted_word = c(unlist(strsplit(word, '')))
  w1 = subset(probs, Letter %in% splitted_word[1])$letter_prob_1
  w2 = subset(probs, Letter %in% splitted_word[2])$letter_prob_2
  w3 = subset(probs, Letter %in% splitted_word[3])$letter_prob_3
  w4 = subset(probs, Letter %in% splitted_word[4])$letter_prob_4
  w5 = subset(probs, Letter %in% splitted_word[5])$letter_prob_5
  estimator = w1 * w2 * w3 * w4 * w5
  return(estimator)
}

gen_letter_probs = function(df){
  new_df = df %>% group_by(Letter) %>% summarise(
  letter_prob_1 = ind_1 / sum(df$ind_1),
  letter_prob_2 = ind_2 / sum(df$ind_2),
  letter_prob_3 = ind_3 / sum(df$ind_3),
  letter_prob_4 = ind_4 / sum(df$ind_4),
  letter_prob_5 = ind_5 / sum(df$ind_5)) # each letter probability by index 
  return(new_df)
}

letter_probs = gen_letter_probs(freq_by_ind)

word_by_estimators = five_letters %>% group_by(Word) %>%  summarise(MLE = generate_est(Word, letter_probs))
word_by_estimators = word_by_estimators[order(word_by_estimators$MLE, decreasing = TRUE), ]
# each word and it's MLE
head(word_by_estimators, 10) # top 10
```

::: {pagedtable="false"}
:::

First, calculated each letter prob by location. To generate MLE we
multiply each relevant prob for each letter in a given word. did as a
data frame for all words and show top 10. we can see tendency for words
ending with e, similar to our heat map.
:::
:::

::: {#b.-function-that-receives-guess-words-corresponding-matches-and-array-of-legal-english-words.-return-all-the-words-in-the-dictionary-that-are-consistent-with-the-results-of-the-previous-guesses .section .level5}
##### b. function that receives guess words, corresponding matches and array of legal English words. return all the words in the dictionary that are consistent with the results of the previous guesses

``` r
words_dict = array(words$V1)

matching_words_func = function(words_dictionary,guess,match_lst){
wanted_match = list()
final_match = c()
  for (i in 1:length(words_dictionary)){
    for (g in 1:length(guess)){
      wanted_match[[g]] = wordle_match(guess[[g]],words_dictionary[i])
      }
      if (identical(wanted_match, match_lst) == TRUE){
        final_match = c(final_match, words_dictionary[i])
      }
    }
  as.vector(final_match)
}

matching_words_func(words_dict,c("south","north"),list(c(-1,1,1,0,0),c(0,1,0,0,0)))
```

    ##  [1] "mouse" "lousy" "louse" "fouls" "douse" "louis" "coups" "mousy" "poufs"
    ## [10] "youse"

Implementing the function of given matches and words gave us the
corresponding vector of words.

**strategy 1:** - We start with a random word with each letter sampled
uniformly and independently from the [\\(26\\)]{.math .inline} English
letters. - Then, at each turn, we look only at the previous perfect
matches (`correct`) to the target word, and ignore matches at the
`wrong` location and missing letters. At each place where there is a
correct match, we use the correct letter, and at all other locations we
keep sampling uniformly from the [\\(26\\)]{.math .inline} letters. We
keep going until we get all the five letters correctly (and hence the
word).
:::
:::

::: {#q6 .section .level3}

::: {#a.-implementing-first-strategy-output-the-number-of-turns-it-took-to-guess-the-word-example-with-the-unknown-word-is-mouse. .section .level5}
### 6. Implementing

``` r
set.seed(3)

gen_word_by_guess = function(ctr,random_letters, right_word, is_printed = FALSE){ # Strategy 1
  vec = random_letters
  guess = paste(vec, collapse = '')
  right_splitted = strsplit(right_word, '')[[1]]
  while (guess != right_word){

    if (vec[1] != right_splitted[1]){
      vec[1] = sample(letters, 1)
      }

    if (vec[2] != right_splitted[2]){
      vec[2] = sample(letters, 1)
      }

    if (vec[3] != right_splitted[3]){
      vec[3] = sample(letters, 1)
      }
    
    if (vec[4] != right_splitted[4]){
      vec[4] = sample(letters, 1)
      }

    if (vec[5] != right_splitted[5]){
      vec[5] = sample(letters, 1)
      }
    
    guess = paste(vec, collapse = '')
    ctr = ctr + 1
    if (is_printed == TRUE){
      print(c(ctr, guess,  paste(wordle_match(guess,right_word), collapse = ' ' )))
    }
  }
    if (is_printed == TRUE){
    paste0(ctr, ' guesses.')}
    else{
    ctr}
  }

wordle_by_strat1 = function(right_word, is_printed){
  random_letters = as.vector(sample(letters, 5))
  rand_word = paste(random_letters, collapse = '')
  num_guess = 1
  if (is_printed == TRUE){
      print(c('Turn: ', ' Guess: ', '  Match:'))
  print(c(num_guess, rand_word, paste(wordle_match(rand_word,right_word), collapse = ' ' )))
    }
  gen_word_by_guess(num_guess, random_letters, right_word, is_printed)
}

wordle_by_strat1("mouse", TRUE)
```

::: {#b.-mathematical-formula-for-the-distribution-of-the-number-of-turns-needed-to-guess-the-target-word-with-strategy-1. .section .level5}
##### b. mathematical formula for the distribution of the number of turns needed to guess the target word with strategy 1.

Define random variable [\\(x_i\\)]{.math .inline} : number of turns
until right guess of single letter in a word. [\\\[ x_i\\sim
{\\sf\^{iid} Geo}(\\frac{1}{26} ) \\\]]{.math .display}

In our case all words are five letter words hence number of turns can be
refered as: [\\\[ \\sum\_{i = 1}\^{5}x_i\\\]]{.math .display} Hence,
[\\\[Pr(\\sum\_{i = 1}\^{5}x_i \< t) = \\prod\_{x = 1}\^{5}1 -
(1-1/26)\^{t-1} =\^{iid} (1 - (1-1/26)\^{t-1})\^5\\\]]{.math .display}
From basic probability we know that: [\\\[Pr(x=t) = Pr(x\<t+1) -
Pr(x\<t) \\\]]{.math .display} Hence: [\\\[Pr(\\sum\_{i = 1}\^{5}x_i =
t) = (1 - (1-1/26)\^{(t+1)-1})\^5 - (1 - (1-1/26)\^{t-1})\^5\\\]]{.math
.display}

[\\\[Pr(\\sum\_{i = 1}\^{5}x_i = t) = (1 - (1-1/26)\^{t})\^5 - (1 -
(1-1/26)\^{t-1})\^5\\\]]{.math .display} Now when we have
[\\(Pr(\\sum\_{i = 1}\^{5}x_i = t)\\)]{.math .inline} we can compute the
expected value.

By the instructions we would not take infinite sum, say we take sum over
2015 (number of five letter words):

``` r
p_five_letters_t = function(t){
  return ((1 - (1-1/26)^t)^5 - (1 - (1-1/26)^(t-1))^5)
}
expected_values = c()
for (t in seq(1, 2015)){
  expected_values= c(expected_values, p_five_letters_t(t)*t)
}

sum(expected_values)
```

    ## [1] 58.71754

(Close result to the number of guesses we got on 6a).
:::

::: {#c.-simulate-strategy-1-a-100-times-with-unknown-words-plot-the-results-and-mean. .section .level5}
##### c.Â simulate strategy 1 a 100 times with unknown words, plot the results and mean.

``` r
set.seed(6)

rand_words = sample(as.vector(words$V1), 100)

turns = c()
for (i in 1:length(rand_words)){
  turns[i] = wordle_by_strat1(rand_words[i], FALSE)
}

probs_to_cumsum = c()
gen_theoretival_cdf = function(probs){
  for (i in 1:100){
    probs[i] = p_five_letters_t(i)
  }
  cumsum(probs)
}
probs_to_cumsum = gen_theoretival_cdf(probs_to_cumsum)

par(mfrow=c(1,2))
plot(ecdf(turns), col = 'darkred', xlim=c(10,190), main = "Emprical CDF") # ecdf of simulation

plot(probs_to_cumsum, col = "skyblue3", main = "Theortical CDF", xlab = 'p_five_letters_t', ylab = 'probabilities')
```

![](data:image/png;base64,){width="672"}

``` r
print(paste0('The average number of turns :' ,mean(turns)))
```

    ## [1] "The average number of turns :56.07"

By viewing both plots we can see that the tendencies match between the
ecdf to the cdf. Also, the empirical expected value we got is 58.71 and
the theoretical expected value is 59.36667 which are similar.

**Strategy 2:** - At each stage, we guess the word with the highest
likelihood (see Qu. 4.c.), **of the remaining words that are consistent
with the previous guesses**. - We keep guessing until obtaining the
correct word.

**Strategy 3:** The same as strategy 2, but at each stage we guess a
random word sampled uniformly from all remaining consistent words
(instead of guessing the word with the highest likelihood).

Run both strategies with the unknown word "mouse", and show the guesses
and the number of turns for them, in similar to Qu. 6.a.
:::
:::

::: {#q7 .section .level3}

::: {#a.-implement-two-additional-strategies-example-with-the-unknown-word-is-mouse .section .level5}
### 7. Implement 2 more strategies

``` r
set.seed(678)

letter_probs2 = gen_letter_probs(words_freq_by_ind)

word_by_estimators2 = words %>% group_by(V1) %>% summarise(MLE = generate_est(V1,letter_probs2))
word_by_estimators2 = word_by_estimators2[order(word_by_estimators2$MLE,
decreasing = TRUE), ]


word_2_dict = as.vector(word_by_estimators2$V1)

wordle_by_strat2 = function(right_word, is_printed){
  
  dict = word_2_dict
  guess = dict[1]
  guess_vec = c(guess)
  ctr = 1
  if (is_printed == TRUE){
      print(c('Turn: ', ' Guess: ', '  Match:'))
  print(c(ctr, guess, paste(wordle_match(guess,right_word), collapse = ' ' )))
    }
  while (guess != right_word){
    dict = matching_words_func(dict, guess,
                                 list(wordle_match(guess,right_word)))
    
    guess = dict[1]
    guess_vec = c(guess_vec, guess)
    ctr = ctr + 1
    if (is_printed == TRUE){
      print(c(ctr, guess,  paste(wordle_match(guess,right_word), collapse = ' ' )))
    }
  }
  if (is_printed == TRUE){
    print(paste0(ctr, ' guesses.'))
    print(guess_vec)}
    else{
    ctr}
}

wordle_by_strat2("mouse", TRUE)
```

    ## [1] "Turn: "   " Guess: " "  Match:"
    ## [1] "1"            "sores"        "-1 1 0 -1 -1"
    ## [1] "2"         "poise"     "0 1 0 1 1"
    ## [1] "3"          "moose"      "1 1 -1 1 1"
    ## [1] "4"         "mouse"     "1 1 1 1 1"
    ## [1] "4 guesses."
    ## [1] "sores" "poise" "moose" "mouse"

``` r
wordle_by_strat3 = function(right_word, is_printed){
  dict = word_2_dict
  guess = sample(dict,1)
  guess_vec = c(guess)
  ctr = 1
  if (is_printed == TRUE){
      print(c('Turn: ', ' Guess: ', '  Match:'))
  print(c(ctr, guess, paste(wordle_match(guess,right_word), collapse = ' ' )))
    }
  while (guess != right_word){
    dict = matching_words_func(dict, guess,
                                 list(wordle_match(guess,right_word)))
    guess = sample(dict,1)
    guess_vec = c(guess_vec, guess)
    ctr = ctr + 1
    if (is_printed == TRUE){
      print(c(ctr, guess,  paste(wordle_match(guess,right_word), collapse = ' ' )))
    }
  }
  if (is_printed == TRUE){
    print(paste0(ctr, ' guesses.'))
    print(guess_vec)}
    else{
    ctr}
}

wordle_by_strat3("mouse", TRUE)
```

    ## [1] "Turn: "   " Guess: " "  Match:"
    ## [1] "1"           "harem"       "0 0 0 -1 -1"
    ## [1] "2"          "munge"      "1 -1 0 0 1"
    ## [1] "3"         "mouse"     "1 1 1 1 1"
    ## [1] "3 guesses."
    ## [1] "harem" "munge" "mouse"

The new strategies seems to be a better approach than the first (naive
implementation). we got much better results for the unknown word
"mouse".
:::

::: {#b.-simulate-both-strategies-a-100-times-with-unknown-words-plot-the-results-and-mean .section .level5}
##### b. simulate both strategies a 100 times with unknown words, plot the results and mean

``` r
set.seed(9)

wordle_by_strat2_light_func = function(right_word){
  dict = word_2_dict
  guess = dict[1]
  ctr = 1
  while(guess != right_word){
    dict = matching_words_func(dict, guess,
                                 list(wordle_match(guess,right_word)))
    
    guess = dict[1]
    ctr = ctr + 1
  }
  ctr
}


rand_words2_3 = sample(word_2_dict, 100)

turns2 = c()
for (i in 1:length(rand_words)){
  turns2[i] = wordle_by_strat2_light_func(rand_words2_3[i])
}
```

``` r
set.seed(9)

wordle_by_strat3_light_func = function(right_word, is_printed){
  dict = word_2_dict
  guess = sample(dict,1)
  ctr = 1
  while(guess != right_word){
    dict = matching_words_func(dict, guess,
                                 list(wordle_match(guess,right_word)))
    guess = sample(dict,1)
    ctr = ctr + 1
  }
  
  ctr
}

rand_words2_3 = sample(word_2_dict, 100)

turns3 = c()
for (i in 1:length(rand_words)){
  turns3[i] = wordle_by_strat3_light_func(rand_words2_3[i])
}
```

``` r
par(mfrow=c(1,2))
```

First, looking at the average number of turns in the simulation we can
confirm that the new methods ar far more efficient. The ecdf for both
strategies looks about the same except for, strategy 2 tend for more
dramatic jumps at the beginning and lower at the end which strategy 3
does less dramatic. Compare to strategy 1 the ecdf looks a lot different
because of the far less moves needed for the guess.
